lang.name: en_CA
lang.key: Maintained by Madison Kelly (mkelly@alteeve.ca) for the Striker.

############################################################################### # # # Alteeve's Niche! #!string!brand_0002!# Configuration # # # # This is the global configuration for the #!string!brand_0002!# dashboard and alert # # monitoring system. Once configured on a dashboard, you can copy it as-is to # # your nodes. # # # ###############################################################################

### Global - These values apply to all #!string!brand_0004!# systems, unless overridden.
# This configures how email is sent from this machine. Please be sure to set # the values below to the values given to you by your mail administrator (if # that's not you). # # This is the mail server to connect to when sending email. smtp::server = #!variable!smtp__server!#
# This is the TCP port used to connect to the mail server. smtp::port = #!variable!smtp__port!#
# This is the email address/IMAP user to send to the mail server. It is also # the address used in the 'From: ' field for emails sent from this machine. # NOTE: If you IMAP user name is not an email address, this may not work (it # has not been tested). If you have trouble, please let us know: # - https://alteeve.ca/w/Support smtp::username = #!variable!smtp__username!#
# This is the password used for the email account above. This can be the # password directly, or a file that contains the password. #smtp::password = file:./email_pw.txt smtp::password = #!variable!smtp__password!#
# This is the security level to use when connecting to the peer, if needed. smtp::security = #!variable!smtp__security!#
# This tells us to use an encrypted connection to the mail server. Set to '0' # to send email plain-text (not recommended!). smtp::encrypt_pass = #!variable!smtp__encrypt_pass!#
# This is the domain given to the mail server when establishing the connection. smtp::helo_domain = #!variable!smtp__helo_domain!#
# This is a comma-separated list of email recipients. Please use bare email # addresses only. mail_data::to = #!variable!mail_data__to!#
# This sets the 'sending domain' when sending email. It should match # smtp::server in most cases. mail_data::sending_domain = #!variable!mail_data__sending_domain!#
### Per-#!string!brand_0004!# Configurations
# This defines each #!string!brand_0004!#. If you want to defined multiple #!string!brand_0004!#s in #!string!brand_0002!#, # copy an entry in this section and increment the variable integer. The order # and value do not matter. It's simply a differentiator. If only one entry # exists, #!string!brand_0002!#'s #!string!brand_0004!# selection screen will not show and the sole entry # will be auto-selected. # # name: Must match the name set in the #!string!brand_0004!#'s 'cluster.conf' file. # nodes: A comma-separated list of nodes. On the #!string!brand_0002!# server, this must # be resolvable to the target machine (ie: via /etc/hosts + # /etc/ssh/ssh_config) # company: A free-form field used to show the owner of the #!string!brand_0004!#. # Particularly useful for resellers and companies with divisions. # description: Also a free-form field used to describe the purpose of the # particular #!string!brand_0004!#. # url: If defined, a link to the given URL will be shown beside the # #!string!brand_0004!#'s name in the Dashboard's #!string!brand_0004!# selection screen. Useful # for linking to internal documentation or similar. # ricci_pw: This is the password used by the 'ricci' user on the #!string!brand_0004!#'s # nodes. It must be set accurately in order to add or remove # servers. If the 'root_pw' is not set below, this password will # be used. # root_pw: This password is used by the dashboard to log into this #!string!brand_0004!#'s # nodes.

############################################################################## # Please do not put any variables other than 'Host' sections below here. # # At this time, only 'Host / Port' is supported. Please use ~/.ssh/config if # # you need to specify additional options for a given host. # ##############################################################################

# The file is maintained by #!string!brand_0002!#. If you modify this manually, entries will # be preserved but formatting and comments will not.
127.0.0.1 localhost localhost.localdomain localhost4 localhost4.localdomain4 ::1 localhost localhost.localdomain localhost6 localhost6.localdomain6
Do not edit this file! Changes will be lost when #!string!brand_0002!# re-writes it.

This is the name of your #!string!brand_0003!#'s cluster name.
This is set in cluster.conf in the element's name="..." attribute.
This is a free-form text field where you can put in any description you would like for the #!string!brand_0003!#.
If you have an internal tracking or documentation system, and if you track the given #!string!brand_0003!# there, you can enter the URL for it here.

This is the name of the company, person or group that owns the specified #!string!brand_0003!#.
This is a purely descriptive field and you can set it to whatever you want.

When your #!string!brand_0003!# was built, a 'ricci' password was set.
Your dashboard needs this password in order to add, edit and remove servers from the given #!string!brand_0003!#.

On most #!string!brand_0003!# systems, the same password is used for both the 'ricci' and 'root' users.
If this is the case for you, you can leave this blank.
If you set a different 'root' password though, please enter that password here.
Please note that both nodes must have the same root password.
The host names of the nodes. Generally, this is xx-cYYnZZ.

Generally, if this machine is in the same place as the the #!string!brand_0003!#, the name you set here will resolve to the '#!string!brand_0005!#' of the node.
If the nodes are on a remote network, and if you (or the owner's admin) setup port forwarding, you will enter their external IP address for both nodes and use different ports.
If you use DNS (or similar) to do name to IP translation, leave this blank.

This is the TCP port used to connect to the node over SSH. If you do not specify this, port 22 will be used.
If the nodes are behind a firewall though, you may need to specify specific port numbers in order to reach each node.
When in doubt, leave this blank.

The dashboard does not send email, but your #!string!brand_0003!# nodes will.
The #!conf!path::an_conf!# that this section manages is designed to be copied unchanged to your nodes, so this information is needed to send alert emails later.

This is the mail server that your node will connect to in order to send email.
Your Internet service provider will give you this address, often called an "SMTP Server".

When connecting to the mail server address above, a specific "port" number must be specified.
Your ISP should mention what this port number along with the address.
Typically, this is "25" for unencrypted connections and "587" for encrypted connections.

Some mail server require a user name and password. Usually, the user name will be you email address.
Some ISPs do not require authentication, and in those cases, this can be left blank.
Please check the information given to you by your ISP to see if this is needed and, if so, what user name to user here.
If you entered a user name above, please enter it's password here.

This controls how, if at all, to encrypt the email traffic between you and the mail server.
As with the other mail settings, which to use will depends on your Internet service provider.
If in doubt, try 'STARTTLS'. If that doesn't work, try 'SSL/TLS'. If that still doesn't work, try 'None'.

This controls whether your password is sent to the mail server in plain text or encrypted.
Most modern mail servers support encrypted passwords, so 'Yes' should work here.

This is the person or list of people who will get alert emails. Please enter just the email address.
Separate multiple email addresses with a comma please.
Example: 'foo@example.com, bar@example.com'.
Any existing open connections to servers may need to be reopened.
The physical disks below are not currently a member of any logical disk.
I am sorry, but without this information, I can not continue.

If you add the server to the #!string!brand_0003!# too early, it will be set to boot off of the #!string!device_0002!# by default, requiring you to update the boot device manually.
If you wait until after the server has rebooted for the first time, then the server will boot off of the #!string!device_0001!# by default.

This can be whatever you want, but it must be unique.
It's good to keep this short.

This fine-tunes the hypervisor for your operating system.
If your OS is not listed, choose the one that is the closest match.

This will open a new window where you can upload new disc images.
Once finished, please reload this page to see them.
You server will boot and install of this disc.

If you need a drivers to install your server,
please select the appropriate disc here.
Most servers work well between 2 and 8 GiB.
Windows servers tend to work best with 2 CPUs.
More is not always better. When in doubt, start with 2 to 4. You can change this easily later.
Please use only one node's storage pool.
Type all to use the all of the available free space.
This is likely a bug in the program.
Save the current configuration of this #!string!brand_0002!# to a file on your computer. This can be used to restore the configuration should this dashboard get reset or replaced.

If you upload a backup configuration file, any existing configuration will be removed and the information in the backup file will be loaded.
Generally, this is done when a dashboard is fresh and there is no existing configuration. If you have a configuration already that you do not want to lose, please do not use this feature.
It would appear that no file was uploaded.
The file #!variable!file!# does not appear to be a valid backup file.
The mimetype detected was #!variable!mimetype!#. The backup file should be 'text/plain'.
The backup file is expected to start with '<!-- Striker Backup -->'.
The backup configuration has been loaded!
Downloading a file from the internet can take a long time!
Please be sure that the web address above is a direct link to the file you want to download.
Some webistes use referal links which may not work here.
If the file you download doesn't work, please delete it from the #!string!brand_0003!# and then download the file yourself.
Once you have the file, you can upload it to the #!string!brand_0003!# from your computer.
This could take a while if the file is big and if your network is slow.
If this is a USB drive, it may have been unplugged.
This could take over ten minutes, depending on the size of the disc and the speed of your optical drive.
This could take a long time, depending on the speed of the connection between Striker and the #!string!brand_0003!#.
This process could take quite some time to complete!
This action can not be undone!
It is possible that another user deleted this file already.
#!string!symbol_0012!# By default, ~256 MiB is set aside for the file system journals.

Once a file transfer starts, it will continue even if you close the page
or the connection times out. If you wish to end the transfer, at this time,
you will need to restart the web server or reboot the dashboard server.
Asking dd to create an image of: [#!variable!device!#] called: [#!variable!name!#] in the: [#!variable!directory!#] directory.

This form is used for creating an #!string!brand_0003!# installation manifest file.
Once generated, you can pass this file to the #!string!app_0001!# and the information in it will be used to configure the node.
The one manifest can be used for both nodes in the #!string!brand_0003!# and to configure replacement nodes.

This is a short prefix that describes the owner or department of this #!string!brand_0003!#.
Generally it is two or three characters long and often is an acronym for the company or department.
This is, ultimately, a free-form field to set as you wish. Please only use alphanumeric characters.
This is the company or department domain name. It will be appended to all host names.

This is a sequence number for this #!string!brand_0003!#.
It is combined with the prefix above and, combined, must be unique across your network(s).
Note: Auto-generating IPs only works up to '25. Beyond that, you need to manually specify the node IPs.
Fill out the rest of the form using default values combined with the "#!string!title_0150!#" answers above.

If you plan to use a /16 subnet for the #!string!brand_0005!#,
you can specify the subnet prefix here to pre-populate the IP addresses below.
The third octal will be derived from the #!string!brand_0003!# sequence number and the fourth octal from the node number.
Note: Clear this value if you plan to use a different subnet size.

If you plan to use a /16 subnet for the #!string!brand_0007!#,
you can specify the subnet prefix here to pre-populate the IP addresses below.
The third octal will be derived from the #!string!brand_0003!# sequence number and the fourth octal from the node number.
Note: Clear this value if you plan to use a different subnet size.

If you plan to use a /16 subnet for the #!string!brand_0009!#,
you can specify the subnet prefix here to pre-populate the IP addresses below.
The third octal will be derived from the #!string!brand_0003!# sequence number and the fourth octal from the node number.
Note: Clear this value if you plan to use a different subnet size.
This is the host name for the first #!string!brand_0003!# node.
This is the host name for the second #!string!brand_0003!# node.

This is the IP address and the subnet of the node's #!string!brand_0005!# interface.
This is the network that will be used for cluster communication, management, fencing and live-migration traffic.
Please use the format "<ip>/<subnet>".

This is the IP address and the subnet of the node's #!string!brand_0007!# interface.
This is the network that all storage data is replicated over.
Please use the format "<ip>/<subnet>".

This is the IP address and the subnet of the node's #!string!brand_0009!# interface.
This is the network all the traffic to and from your servers will travel over.
Please use the format "<ip>/<subnet>".

This is the IP address and subnet of the node's IPMI Interface.
It may be called by other names, like "iRMC", "iLO", "iDRAC", "RSA" or so on, depending on your hardware vendor.
This will be the node's primary fence method.
Please use the format "<ip>/<subnet>".
This is the host name for the first UPS.

This is the IP address and subnet of the first UPS.
If you don't have a UPS, or your UPS does not have a network card, you can leave this blank.
Please use the format "<ip>/<subnet>".
This is the host name for the second UPS.

This is the IP address and subnet of the second UPS.
If you don't have two UPSes, or your UPSes do not have network cards, you can leave this blank.
Please use the format "<ip>/<subnet>".
This is the host name for the first Switched PDU.

This is the IP address and subnet of the first switched PDU.
This is part of the backup fence method, so making sure this is right is very important.
Also carefully note which outlet powers which node, you will need to enter that information further below.
Please use the format "<ip>/<subnet>".
This is the host name for the second Switched PDU.

This is the IP address and subnet of the second switched PDU.
This is the other part of the backup fence method, so making sure this is right is also very important.
Also carefully note which outlet powers which node, you will need to enter that information further below.
Please use the format "<ip>/<subnet>".

This is the host name for the first network switch.
If you manage your switches using a serial interface, or if your switches are unmanaged, you can leave this blank.

This is the IP address and subnet of the first network switch.
This isn't very important and can safely be left blank.
It is helpful in that it will add an entry to each node's '/etc/hosts making it easier to connect to it using it's host name.
Please use the format "<ip>/<subnet>".

This is the host name for the second network switch.
It may only be useful if you break the switch stack, and can often be safely omitted.

This is the IP address and subnet of the second network switch.
This isn't very important and can safely be left blank, particularly in stacked switch environments.
It is helpful in that it will add an entry to each node's '/etc/hosts making it easier to connect to it using it's host name.
Please use the format "<ip>/<subnet>".

This is the host name for the first #!string!brand_0002!# dashboard.
This name, along with the IP addresses below, is used to populate each node's "<ip>/<subnet>" file.
It serves no other purpose and can be left blank if you prefer not to set it.

This is the IP address for the first #!string!brand_0002!# dashboard's #!string!brand_0005!# connection.
Please use the format "<ip>/<subnet>".

This is the IP address for the first #!string!brand_0002!# dashboard's #!string!brand_0009!# connection.
Please use the format "<ip>/<subnet>".

This is the host name for the second #!string!brand_0002!# dashboard, if you have one.
This name, along with the IP addresses below, is used to populate each node's "<ip>/<subnet>" file.
It serves no other purpose and can be left blank if you prefer not to set it.

This is the IP address for the second #!string!brand_0002!# dashboard's #!string!brand_0005!# connection.
Please use the format "<ip>/<subnet>".

This is the IP address for the second #!string!brand_0002!# dashboard's #!string!brand_0009!# connection.
Please use the format "<ip>/<subnet>".

This is the dafault gateway used to access the Internet on the #!string!brand_0009!# interface.
If your nodes will not have access to the Internet, you can leave this blank.

This is the primary domain name server used to resolve hostnames to IP address when the given host name was not found in /etc/hosts.
The default IP address of 8.8.8.8 is one of Google's open DNS servers.
If your nodes will not have access to the Internet, you can leave this blank.

This is the secondary domain name server used to resolve hostnames to IP address when the given host name was not found in /etc/hosts.
The default IP address of 8.8.4.4 is the other of Google's open DNS servers.
If your nodes will not have access to the Internet, you can leave this blank.

This is the name of this #!string!brand_0003!# in the HA cluster stack's /etc/cluster/cluster.conf file.
Generally it will be in the format "-#!string!brand_0013!#-".
Configure the nodes for this new #!string!brand_0003!# and, if you wish, override global settings.

Configure the nodes for this #!string!brand_0003!# and, if you wish, override global settings.
To remove this #!string!brand_0003!#, click on the 'X' icon beside the name to clear all fields and then save the form.

The values you set here will be used for this #!string!brand_0003!#, overridding the global values. You can override any or all values.
To use the global values, enter "#!inherit!#".
Select an #!string!brand_0003!# to modify or delete.
The values you set here will be the default for all your #!string!brand_0003!# systems. You will be able to override any of these settings per-#!string!brand_0003!# below.
Restarting the remote desktop server on this dashboard.
Updating the #!variable!server!# server's CPU, RAM and boot devices...
Requested RAM was higher than available.
Requested CPU count was higher than available.
You need to power off the server for the changes to take effect.
There are two ways to do this:
It looks like neither the amount of RAM or the number of CPUs has changed.
Adding the new #!variable!server!# server to the #!string!brand_0003!#'s #!variable!failover_domain!# failover domain.
About to join both nodes to the #!variable!anvil!# #!string!brand_0003!#.
About to forcefully power off the #!string!brand_0003!# node #!variable!node_anvil_name!#!
About to power down the physical node #!variable!node_anvil_name!#!
About to power on the physical node #!variable!node_anvil_name!#!
About to power on both nodes!
About to boot up the server #!variable!server!# on #!variable!node_anvil_name!#
About to shut down the server #!variable!server!#!
About to migrate the server #!variable!server!# to #!variable!target!#.
Attempting orderly shut down of #!variable!server!# now...
Attempting to join both nodes to the #!variable!anvil!# #!string!brand_0003!# now...
Joining of both nodes to the #!variable!anvil!# #!string!brand_0003!# aborted!
Begining the process of deleting #!variable!server!# now...
Removing the server from the #!string!brand_0003!#'s management:
The server appears to still be running. I will force it off now.
Freeing up the server's storage now.
Powering on both nodes in the #!string!brand_0003!# now...
Booting both nodes in the #!variable!anvil!# #!string!brand_0003!# aborted!
Attempting to recover the resource manager and, if necessary, the node's storage services...
No shared file systems were found.
Unable to connect to the #!replace!anvil!# cluster!
Backup your current configuration or load a saved configuration
About to download from the web directly to the #!variable!anvil!# #!string!brand_0003!#.
Uploading the file to the #!string!brand_0003!#'s storage.
Upload to the server is starting.
About to create a disc image and upload it to the #!string!brand_0003!#: [#!variable!anvil!#].
Files already on the shared space:
Create an image of your disc and upload it to the #!string!brand_0003!#.
Download directly from a website address to the #!string!brand_0003!#.
Upload a file from your computer.

No #!string!brand_0003!# yet configured.
Click #!string!row_0017!# to add your first one!
Configure the common variables that are used for all #!string!brand_0003!# systems.

I am sorry, but I can not find an #!string!brand_0003!# called #!variable!anvil!# in the configuration file.

Please update /etc/an/an.conf in order to add a new #!string!brand_0003!# to this dashboard server.

You appear to have tried to save an empty new #!string!brand_0003!#.
At minimum, the '#!string!row_0005!#', '#!string!row_0006!# and '#!string!row_0007!#' must be specified.

The #!string!brand_0003!# with ID #!variable!id!# is missing some data.
At minimum, the '#!string!row_0005!#', '#!string!row_0006!# and '#!string!row_0007!#' must be specified.
The IP address assigned to #!string!brand_0003!# #!variable!name!#'s node named #!variable!node!# appears to be invalid.

The TCP port assigned to #!string!brand_0003!# #!variable!name!#'s node named #!variable!node!# appears to be invalid.
A TCP port needs to be a number between '1' and '65535'.
Node 1 in #!string!brand_0003!# #!variable!name!# appears to be missing.
Node 2 in #!string!brand_0003!# $this_name appears to be missing.
The email address #!variable!email!# does not appear to be valid.
The mail server port needs to be a number between '1' and '65535'.

You need to specify what TCP your mail server is listening on.
Usually this is either '25' or '587'.
Everything seems sensible, ready to save.

Failed to copy the file #!variable!file!# to #!variable!destination!#.
Shell call output:
#!variable!output!#
Please fix the issues found above. Once ready, please try again.

Unable to connect to #!variable!node!#.
It is on an accessible subnet, so the node is likely off or there is a network problem.
If you just powered on the node, please be patient, it might still be booting.

Unable to connect to #!variable!node!#.
The server running #!string!brand_0002!# is not currently on the same subnet as the node.

SSH host key validation failed.
Have you saved #!variable!node!#'s fingerprint in $conf->{'system'}{username}'s ~/.ssh/known_hosts file?
If this is a new issue, the physical node may have changed, requiring the old fingerprint be deleted and the new fingerprint be saved.
If the machine has not changed, then this might be a sign of an attempt to intercept your connection to the node.
Could not resolve the hostname: #!variable!node!#. Have you setup your /etc/hosts file or DNS server properly?
I could not log into: #!variable!node!#. Is the "#!string!row_0025!#" correct in this #!string!brand_0003!#? Check /var/log/secure on #!variable!node!# for errors.

I could not log into: #!variable!node!#.
If you just powered the node on or off, it may not be allowing connections.
Please try again shortly.

I could not log into: #!variable!node!#.
The connection timed out.

I could not log into: #!variable!node!#.
The network is not reachable. Is this machine hosting this program on the same subnet?

I could not log into: #!variable!node!#. It appears that the node's operating system has changed! If this node failed and was replaced, be sure to remove the old key from #!conf!system::username!#'s ~/.ssh/known_hosts file. If the node has not been replaced, then someone might be trying to trick you into logging into it.

I could not reach either node in this #!string!brand_0003!#.
There may be useful information in the message above.

I could not reach either node in this #!string!brand_0003!#.
There may be useful information in the message above.
There is no cache file for this system, so either it was deleted or this is the first time you have tried to connect.
In either case, please manually power on the nodes when you are ready to use them.
If they are on and you are seeing this message, then there might be a network problem.
Is this machine on the #!string!brand_0003!#'s #!string!brand_0005!#?
The number #!variable!number!# passed into the 'comma()' function contains a non-digit character or too many decimals.
The passed byte size #!variable!size!# contains an illegal value. Byte sizes can only be signed integers. It may also have commas in it which will be removed automatically.

The passed byte size #!variable!size!# in the string: [sign: #!variable!sign!#, size: #!variable!size!#, type: #!variable!type!#] contains an illegal value.
Sizes can only be integers or real numbers. It may also have commas in it which will be removed automatically.
This is probably a program error (#!variable!file!#, line #!variable!line!#)

The passed size: #!variable!size!#, type: #!variable!type!# is not recognized.
Either an invalid size type was passed or I failed to properly parse the size type.
Valid size types are: 'b', 'k', 'm', 'g', 't', 'p', 'e', 'z' or 'y'.
This is probably a program error (#!variable!file!#, line #!variable!line!#)

I was unable to talk to: #!variable!node!#, but it is reported as being powered on.
If you just powered on this system, please wait a moment for it to boot.
If you just powered off this node, it might still be shutting down.
Otherwise, the node may have crashed.

I was unable to talk to: #!variable!node!#, nor can I contact it's out of band management interface to determine it's current power state.
The out of band management interface's address, user name or password may have changed since it was last cached.
Please manually check the Anvil's cluster and update the cluster's fencing information if needed.

I was unable to talk to: #!variable!node!#, nor can I contact it's out of band management interface to determine it's current power state.
The machine running the dashboard is not on the same subnet as the out of band management, so the node's current state is unknown.

I was unable to talk to: #!variable!node!#, nor can I contact it's out of band management interface to determine it's current power state.
Please check the network connections between this machine and the nodes.
If the power feeding the node was cut at the PDUs, fencing the node may restore access.
Host name #!variable!node!# does not resolve to an IP address.

Connection to #!variable!node!# on port #!variable!port!# as the user #!variable!user!# was refused.
If you recently booted this server, it may be just about finished booting.
It is normal for the connection to be refused for a brief time during the boot process.

No route to: #!variable!node!#.
Is the machine in the process of booting up or powering off?
Is this dashboard server on the same network?

Timed out while waiting for a reply from #!variable!node!#.
Is the machine booting up?
If so, please wait a minute or two and try again.
Unable to log in. Please check the password for this #!string!brand_0003!#.

One of more of the storage daemons are running on #!variable!node!# while the #!string!brand_0003!#'s cluster is down.
#!string!brand_0011!#

The logical volume #!variable!lv!# on node #!variable!node!# is inactive!
Please contact support, or if you are comfortable, active the LV as soon as possible.

There was a problem when scanning the storage. The nodes report different sizes and/or volume groups for the logical volume #!variable!lv!#. Saw sizes #!variable!size!# vs. #!variable!bytes!# and the backing volume group is #!variable!vg_1!# vs. #!variable!vg_2!#.

I was asked to check the power staus of #!variable!node!# via it's peer #!variable!peer!#, but the power check command is empty.
This is likely a program error.

I was trying to resolve the host name #!variable!target_host!# but was unable to do so.
Is this a valid host name? If so, do you have an entry in DNS or in your /etc/hosts file?
I was trying to resolve a host name, but no name was given. This is likely a program error.

Failed to write #!variable!cache_file!# as UID #!variable!uid!#.
The error was: #!variable!errer!#

I am sorry, but I did not find any storage management tools on #!variable!node!#.
Please install MegaCli64 or another supported storage manager and try again.

Please close this brower tab (or window).
You should now be able to connect to your server.
Rebuild will begin in just a moment.

You've requested that the new RAM for this server be #!variable!requested_ram!#.
Unfortunately, the highest you can use is #!variable!max_ram!#.
Did someone else allocate some of the free RAM to another server?
No changes were made.

You've requested that the CPU count for this server be #!variable!requested_cpus!#.
Unfortunately, the highest you can use is #!variable!max_cpus!#.
No changes were made.
Setting the RAM to #!variable!ram!# #!variable!ram_suffix!#, the number of CPUs to #!variable!requested_cpus!# and the boot device to '#!variable!requested_boot_device!#'.
Gracefully power off and then boot back up the server.

While logged into your server, directly shut the OS down.
  The #!string!brand_0003!# will automatically restart the server with the new settings.
Please don't just reboot. The configuration file is read on initial boot only.
No change was made to the server.
It looks like someone else already inserted a disc.
It would appear that something went wrong!
I tried to insert the disc #!variable!media!# into the drive #!variable!drive!# and the command should have returned [0], but [#!variable!virsh_exit_code!#] was received.
It would appear that someone else already ejected the disc.
The optical drive's media has been ejected.
I tried to eject the disc in drive #!variable!drive!# and the command should have returned [0], but [#!variable!virsh_exit_code!#] was received.

I am sorry, but the #!string!brand_0003!#'s storage isn't running on either node.
Please try again once the #!string!brand_0003!#'s storage has started on at least one of the nodes.

The server is currently not using VNC. The server's configuration will be updated now.
Please power off and then start the server (don't reboot) and then try again.
Connect directly to this server's desktop.
I think this server is running, but I don't know where. You can try connecting to it anyway.

This version of #!string!brand_0002!# does not have in-browser remote desktop support yet.
Please upgrade to enable this feature.

Please Note: If the server is migrated to the other node,
you will have to refresh this page and then reconnect.

If you're having trouble connecting to the server's desktop,
first make sure no one else is connected to the server already
(via #!string!brand_0002!# or another program like "Virtual Machine Manager").
If no one is, #!string!button_0020!#.
This will restart the remote desktop server on this dashboard.
I tried to update the definition file for #!variable!server!# and the command should have returned [0], but [#!variable!virsh_exit_code!#] was received.
Unable to add the new #!variable!server!# server to the #!string!brand_0003!# without a ricci password!
Please update the #!string!row_0024!# for this #!string!brand_0003!# and then try again by pressing '<ctrl> + r'.

I was unable to determine which failover domain to use for this new machine.
Were the primary_n0* failover domains added to the #!string!brand_0003!#'s /etc/cluster/cluster.conf configuration?
Checking now to make sure the new server is up and running.
It is not running at the moment, I will now boot the server.
It should now be booting up.
It didn't start on the first try. Trying again specifying the definition file.

The new #!variable!server!# server didn't start on reboot.
I tried to start it, but the command should have returned 0, but #!variable!virsh_exit_code!# was received.
It is already running, as expected.
The server is now running on the peer. I will use that node for the next steps.

The #!string!brand_0003!# needs to know what "hardware" to create for the new server when it starts.
This is done using a "definition" file, which we will record now.
I was about to add a server to the #!string!brand_0003!# but I don't have the new server's name. This is likely a software error.
I tried to record the definition file and the command should have returned 0, but #!variable!virsh_exit_code!# was received.
To ensure only the Anvil! can start the server, the libvirtd definition will now be removed.
I tried to remove the libvirtd definition, which should have returned 0, but #!variable!virsh_exit_code!# was received.
This is a non-fatal error. Proceeding.
I will now add the new server to the #!string!brand_0003!#.
This can take several minutes to complete.
#!string!row_0044!#: The ricci daemon is not running on $node.
This is probably a mis-configuration of the #!string!brand_0003!# node.
Please ensure that ricci is running and is set to start on boot.
The server has been added successfully.
The call to add the new server to the #!string!brand_0003!# should have returned 0, but #!variable!ccs_exit_code!# was received.
Informing the #!string!brand_0003!# that the server is running.
The server has been added to the #!string!brand_0003!#.
The call to tell the #!string!brand_0003!# that the new server is running should have returned 0, but #!variable!clusvcadm_exit_code!# was received.
In just a moment, your new server should begin installing.
Please leave this window open until you have rebooted the new server for the first time!

Failed to locate the host node!
Please use #!string!device_0004!# on the dashboard machine to locate this server and finish the install. Sorry for the inconvenience.
If there were no errors, the installation should now have started.
Directly connect to your new server's desktop.
Once the installation is complete, please return here and click the link below.
Please complete the install using the #!string!device_0004!# on the dashboard's desktop.
After the first reboot, #!string!button_0020!# to add the server to the #!string!brand_0003!#.
The server name can't have spaces in the name.
The server name #!variable!server!# is already in use.
All servers need to have a name. This is usally something like vmXX-purpose.
Somehow, the number of requested CPUs #!variable!cpu_cores!# has a non-digit in it. This is probably a program error.
The #!string!brand_0003!# reports a maximum of #!variable!total_threads!# CPUs, but it looks like you asked for #!variable!cpu_cores!#. This is probably a program error.
The amount of RAM must only contain digits. It looks like you entered #!variable!ram!#.
The #!string!brand_0003!# reports a maximum of #!variable!free_ram!# free RAM, but it looks like you asked for #!variable!requested_ram!#. Did someone else just build a server?
It looks like you asked to use storage from both nodes. This is not safe. Please clear one of the node's storage.
The installation media you selected seems to have disappeared.
You did not select installation media.
The driver media you selected seems to have disappeared.
Somehow, an OS optimization type was specified that is not valid. This is probably a program error.
No operating system optimization type was specified. This is probably a program error.
Create a new server on the #!variable!anvil!# #!string!brand_0003!#
You will need to answer some questions in order to create a new server.
If you are unsure what a certain question means, please don't hesitate to ask questions.
Once withdrawn, it will no longer be able to run or recover any servers until it rejoins the #!string!brand_0003!#.
This will attempt to join the node #!variable!node_anvil_name!# to the #!string!brand_0003!#.
This is usually a safe action.
If, for any reason, this node can't connect to it's peer, the peer node could be fenced (forcibly shut off).
This will attempt to join both nodes of the #!variable!anvil!# #!string!brand_0003!#.
The #!string!brand_0003!# node #!variable!node_anvil_name!# is about to be forcibly powered off!
This will effectively press and hold your node's power button until the system is forced to power down.
Should that fail, the power to the node will be completely cut off.
This should be done as a last resort, when all other attempts to gracefully shut down the node have failed.
Every operating system has a chance of corrupting when it is forcibly powered off.
This will send a poweroff command to the #!variable!node_anvil_name!# node.
If all is well, this node should gracefully power off.
If there is a problem with this node, like an incomplete withdrawl from the #!string!brand_0003!#, it may hang while trying to shut down.
If this happens, return to the previous page and call a fence action against this node.
An attempt will be made to power on the #!variable!node_anvil_name!# node.
An attempt will be made to boot both nodes in the #!variable!anvil!# #!string!brand_0003!#.
Please be patient, it can take a few minutes for the nodes to become accessible.
The server named #!variable!server!# will be booted on the #!string!brand_0003!# node #!variable!node_anvil_name!#.
The node was selected because it is either the preferred host or the only host ready to run this server.
The server named #!variable!server!#, running on the #!string!brand_0003!# node #!variable!node_anvil_name!#, is about to be shut down.

If #!variable!server!# is not listening to ACPI calls, this attempt to shut down the node will fail!
Make sure that Linux machines are running acpid and that Windows machines have no pending updates.
If #!variable!server!# doesn't shut down within 120 seconds, it will be forced off!

Before proceeding, it is strongly advised that you connect to the server.
If there are updates pending, please reboot the server first.
This will ensure that server shuts down cleanly.
The server named #!variable!server!#, running on the #!string!brand_0003!# node #!variable!host!#, is about to be forcibly powered off!
This action is the same as pulling the power on a hardware server!
The server will have no chance to react and will be instantly turned off. A moment later, the #!string!brand_0003!# will restart this server.
This should be done as a last resort, when all other attempts to gain control of the server have failed.
This is a permanent and irreversable action!
The server, along with all of it's data, will be deleted.
It will be removed from the #!string!brand_0003!#'s management and forced off, if necessary.
The definition file will be deleted and it's backing storage will be removed.
Ensure you have backed up any data on the machine before proceeding!

The server named #!variable!server!# will be migrated to the #!string!brand_0003!# node #!variable!target!#.
This server has #!variable!ram!# RAM, which will take roughly #!variable!migration_time_estimate!# seconds to migrate.
The server named #!variable!server!# will be destroyed and deleted!
It looks like the attempt to start the server Failed. Will try to recover now...
Trying again to start the server...
It looks like there is a problem with this server.
It appears that node #!variable!message!# is no longer ready to run #!variable!server!#.
This could be because some time has passed and the state of the node has changed.
Please go back to the status page for more details.
It appears that node #!variable!target!# is no longer ready to run #!variable!server!#.
This can take a while, please be patient!

This process will complete before the storage services start.
Please give a minute or two for storage to come online.
It appears that #!variable!node!# has already joined the #!string!brand_0003!#.
Output from both nodes will be mixed together and may cause unusual formatting. This is not a problem.
All children should be gone now but it seems the program went into an infinit loop.
If the server powered off properly, the #!string!brand_0003!# should boot it back up in a moment.
#!string!brand_0002!# appears to have failed to read the server's information properly.
Can't delete #!variable!server!# until at least one node is online.
The server has been successfully removed.
The removal call should have exited with exit code 0, but #!variable!ccs_exit_code!# was received.
The server has been forced off.
The call to destroy the server should have exited with exit code '0', but '#!variable!virsh_exit_code!#' was received instead.
It would appear that #!variable!lv!# was not removed.
The call to remove the server's storage should have exited with exit code 0, but #!variable!lvremove_exit_code!# was received.
It would appear that something went very wrong!
I was asked to delete the server definition file #!variable!file!#, which does not belong to the #!string!brand_0003!#.
For security reasons, only files in /shared/definitions/ can be deleted.

I tried to delete the file #!variable!file!# and then verify that it was indeed removed.
This should have returned 2, but #!variable!ls_exit_code!# was returned instead.

The file: [#!variable!file!#] has been archived as:
[#!variable!destination!#].

I tried to archive the file #!variable!file!# as #!variable!destination!#.
This should have returned 0, but #!variable!cp_exit_code!# was returned instead.

This will complete once #!variable!node_anvil_name!# has closed the connection.
It may take a minute before the node shows as powered off on the dashboard.
It appears that node #!variable!node_anvil_name!# is either already off or it is now in use by a server.
I was asked to power on #!variable!node!#, but the command to do so was not found in the cache. Manual power up is required.
I was asked to power on #!variable!node!#, but it appears to already be running. Start up aborted.

I was asked to power on #!variable!node!#, but I am not able to log into the taget node's out of band management interface #!variable!target_host!#.
Please check to see if the address, user or password has changed. Unable to continue.

I was asked to power on #!variable!node!#, but I am not on the same subnet as it's out of band management interface at #!variable!target_host!#.
Please restore access to the target subnet. Unable to continue.

I was asked to power on #!variable!node!#, but I don't have a recorded method of checking or changing the power state for #!variable!target_host!#.
Please restore access to the target subnet. Unable to continue.
I will now try to power on both nodes in the #!variable!anvil!# #!string!brand_0003!#.
It may take a few minutes before the dashboard can log into either node.
I will now try to power on #!variable!node_anvil_name!#.
It may take a few minutes before the dashboard can log into it.
An unknown error has occured. Is #!variable!node!#'s IPMI interface reachable?
The node #!variable!node_anvil_name!# is already reported as being powered up.
The node #!variable!node_anvil_name!#'s out of band management interface is currently unreachable.

I was asked to power on #!variable!node!# via it's peer #!variable!peer!#, but the power command is empty.
This is likely a program error.
I wasn't able to find the command needed to power on #!variable!node_anvil_name!#.
Either this node has not been seen before or the cache for this node was deleted.
You can not power on the node from the dashboard at this time.
Unable to determine the commands needed to fence #!variable!node!#. One of the nodes need to be accessible or the cache file must exist with the correct command.

Trying to fence #!variable!node!#, but it's peer, #!variable!peer!#, is also offline and the fence device at #!variable!address!# is not accessible from this machine.
Unable to proceed with fence action.
I will now attempt to fence #!variable!node_anvil_name!#.
Fencing using the #!variable!method_name!# method succeeded. Proceeding with unfence action.
Fencing using the #!variable!method_name!# method failed. Will try next method, if available.
Unfencing using the #!variable!method_name!# method succeeded. Fence operation a complete success!

Unfencing using the #!variable!method_name!# method failed.
\nThe core fence action was a success, but something went wrong and manual intervention may be required before the node can be returned to service.
\nIf another fence method remains, it will now be tried in hopes of assisting recovery.
The #!string!brand_0003!#'s communication layer failed to stop!
Was something holding open the #!string!brand_0003!#'s storage?
If a shell was logged in and sitting in the /shared directory, a failure like this can occur.
Unable to start the #!string!brand_0003!#'s communication layer!
It appears that node #!variable!node_anvil_name!# is now in use by a server.
This requires a rescan of the #!string!brand_0003!#, please be patient.
The #!variable!storage_service!# storage will now be cycled...
The #!variable!storage_service!# storage service has been disabled.
Please log into #!variable!node!# and locate what held open the storage service.
Trying to withdraw from the #!string!brand_0003!# before this is fixed could cause problems.
The #!variable!storage_service!# storage service failed to restart!
The #!variable!storage_service!# storage service failed to disable!
The #!variable!storage_service!# storage service appears to be ok!
Recovery of the storage services appears to be unnecessary.
Unable to identify the storage service for this node! This is likely a program error.
Failed to restart the resource manager daemon!
Both physical nodes appear to be powered off. Your #!string!brand_0003!# details are not available at this time.
Unable to connect to either #!string!brand_0003!# node. The status is not available at this time.

I found a server with the name #!variable!server!# which is not managed by the #!string!brand_0003!# yet.
If this is a new server that is still being installed, please ignore this message.
If you do not have the original dashboard install window open anymore, you can click here to add it to this #!string!brand_0003!# now.
This could take a minute to complete.

I was asked to call: '#!variable!shell_call!#' but no node was defined.
This is probably a program error, sorry about the inconvenience. Please contact support and we will try to help fix this.
Unable to connect to either node in the #!string!brand_0003!#.
Please ensure both nodes are online, and then try pushing the configuration again.
To prevent configuration divergence, both nodes must be online and accessible.
The #!variable!node!# node's ssh fingerprint has not been recorded yet, doing so now...

On the #!variable!node!# node, I am backing up the: #!variable!source!# file to: #!variable!destination!#.
If the #!variable!source!# does not exist, you will see a harmless error below.
View or upate the system configuration for this #!string!brand_0002!#.
Progress: #!variable!percent!#% finished, #!variable!received!# downloaded at ~ #!variable!rate!# MiB/sec.
Will be downloaded directly to the #!variable!anvil!# #!string!brand_0003!#.
It appears you clicked '#!string!button_0042!#' without first selecting a file.
Please go back and try again.
It looks like the upload failed.
It looks like the upload succeeded.
There is a file on the #!string!brand_0003!# called #!variable!name!# on the #!string!brand_0003!#.
Please go back and give the file a different name.
The drive in #!variable!device!# appears to no longer exist!
The drive in #!variable!device!# appears to not be ready.
Please reload to try and read the disc again.
The disc in #!variable!device!# appears to have been removed.
Please reinsert the disc and then reload this page.
It looks like the upload failed.
It looks like the upload succeeded, unlinking the source image.
The disc will be converted into an image file.
For a DVD, this could take around 10 minutes to complete.
The image will be uploaded to the #!string!brand_0003!#'s #!conf!path::shared!# directory.
If the #!string!brand_0003!# is remote and your internet connection is slow, this could take a very long time.
This is the name that will be given to the DVD or CD image.
Any output from the shell will be below (none expected):
The file #!variable!name!# on the #!variable!anvil!# #!string!brand_0003!# is already gone.
The directory: #!variable!directory!# is not readible by the #!variable!user!# user.
Disc read failed, please reload to try again.

If the server hosting this file is slow or if the file is big,
the download might take a long time to complete.
There is no confirmation for this action.
Uploading a big file over a slow link might take a long time.
I am sorry, but I can not connect to either node in the #!variable!anvil!# #!string!brand_0003!#.

When on the remote machine, you can access an on-screen keyboard
by pressing the left '<ctrl> + <alt> + <shift>' keys at the same time.

If you are using a tablet or phone,
place your finger left of your screen and swipe towards the right.

Failed to create the provision script: [#!variable!provision_script!#].
Has the /shared/provision, /shared/archives, /shared/files and /shared/definitions directories been created?
No name was given for the disc image to be created.
No disc drive device name was given. This is probably a program error. #!string!brand_0011!#.
It looks like the name you gave matched an existing directory name.

The 'expect' program is not installed (or it was not found at '#!conf!path::expect!#').
If you have not setup passwordless SSH, then access to the node(s) will fail.
Restart appears to have failed, trying again.
Restart failed too many times, giving up. #!string!brand_0011!#
It looks like there was a program error!

I was about to write the new definition file: [#!variable!definition_file!#],
but it appears the contents are empty.

I was about to write the new definition file: [#!variable!definition_file!#],
but it appears the contents are not formed properly.

After trying to write the new definition file: [#!variable!definition_file!#],
a check was made and the file was deemed to be corrupt. The original file was restored from backup file: [#!replace!backup_file!#], which was created just before the new file was written.

I was asked to uptade the new definition file: [#!variable!definition_file!#],
but it appears that I don't have the original definition file's contents.
The definition file needs to be updated to switch the Server's graphics to VNC.
Add an existing #!string!brand_0004!# to this #!string!brand_0002!# dashboard.
Backup this #!string!brand_0002!#'s configuration or load a saved configuration file.
Create an installation manifest for new #!string!brand_0004!# node(s).
Successfully unmarked the disk #!variable!disk!# on adapter ##!variable!disk!# as a hot-spare.

Failed to unmark the disk #!variable!disk!# on adapter ##!variable!adapter!# as a hot-spare.

Message from the controller:

#!variable!message!#
Successfully marked the disk #!variable!disk!# on adapter ##!variable!adapter!# as a global hot-spare.

Failed to mark the disk #!variable!disk!# on adapter ##!variable!adapter!# as a global hot-spare.

Message from the controller:

#!variable!message!#
Successfully marked disk #!variable!disk!# on adapter ##!variable!adapter!# as missing.

Failed to mark the disk #!variable!disk!# on adapter ##!variable!adapter!# as missing.

Message from the controller:

#!variable!message!#
Unable to mark the disk #!variable!disk!# on adapter ##!variable!adapter!# as missing. May not be be required, proceeding with spin-down.
Successfully spun up the disk #!variable!disk!# on adapter ##!variable!adapter!#.

Failed to spin up the disk #!variable!disk!# on adapter ##!variable!adapter!#.

Message from the controller:

#!variable!message!#

Successfully spun down the disk #!variable!disk!# on adapter ##!variable!adapter!# online.

It can now be safely removed.

Failed to spin down the disk #!variable!disk!# on adapter ##!variable!adapter!# online.

It is not safe to remove!

Message from the controller:

#!variable!message!#

Unable to spin down the disk #!variable!disk!# on adapter ##!variable!adapter!# online, firmware rejected the request.

Will try to mark the disk as 'Unconfigured(good)' and then try again.
Putting this disk offline would destroy the array and cause data loss.
Please replace the array's failed disk before taking this disk offline.

The physical disk: #!variable!disk!# is a member of the degraded logical disk: #!variable!logical_disk!#.

#!variable!reason!#

This will take the disk #!variable!disk!# offline, removing it from logical disk #!variable!logical_disk!#.

This will degrade the array!

Please do not proceed until you have the replacement drive ready to install.
This will take the disk #!variable!disk!# offline, preparing it for physical removal.

Are you sure you wish to proceed?

#!string!button_0004!# - #!string!message_0140!# - #!string!button_0005!#
Successfully put the disk #!variable!disk!# on adapter ##!variable!adapter!# offline.

Failed to put the disk #!variable!disk!# on adapter ##!variable!adapter!# offline.

Message from the controller:

#!variable!message!#
Successfully put the disk #!variable!disk!# on adapter ##!variable!adapter!# online.

Failed to put the disk #!variable!disk!# on adapter ##!variable!adapter!# online.

Message from the controller:

#!variable!message!#
Successfully added the disk #!variable!disk!# on adapter ##!variable!adapter!# to logical disk ##!variable!logical_disk!#.

Failed to add the disk #!variable!disk!# on adapter ##!variable!adapter!# to logical disk ##!variable!logical_disk!#.

Message from the controller:

#!variable!message!#
Add Physical Disk to Logical Disk
Successfully marked the disk #!variable!disk!# on adapter ##!variable!adapter!# as good.

Failed to mark the disk #!variable!disk!# on adapter ##!variable!adapter!# as good.

Message from the controller:

#!variable!message!#
Successfully #!variable!action!# the disk ID LED for #!variable!disk!# on adapter ##!variable!adapter!#.

Failed to #!variable!action!# the disk ID LED for #!variable!disk!# on adapter ##!variable!adapter!#.

Message from the controller:

#!variable!message!#
- Missing disk in row #!variable!row!#, replace with #!variable!minimum_size!# or larger.

Failed to clear foreign configurations on adapter ##!variable!adapter!#.

Message from the controller:

#!variable!message!#
